triples.evidence: Modern solid-state drives (SSDs) use new hostâ€“interface protocols, such as NVMe, to provide applications with fast access to storage.
As more SSDs are deployed in data-centers and enterprise platforms, there has been a continued need to improve SSD performance.
As more SSDs are deployed in data-centers and enterprise platforms, there has been a continued need to improve SSD performance.
FLIN is implemented fully within the SSD controller firmware, requiring no new hardware, and has negligible (<0.06%) storage cost.

Compared to a state-of-the-art I/O scheduler, FLIN improves the fairness and performance of a wide range of enterprise and datacenter storage workloads, with an average improvement of 70% and 47%, respectively.

Compared to a state-of-the-art I/O scheduler, FLIN improves the fairness and performance of a wide range of enterprise and datacenter storage workloads, with an average improvement of 70% and 47%, respectively.
These new protocols make use of a concept known as the multi-queue SSD (MQ-SSD), where the SSD has direct access to the application-level I/O request queues.

We perform a comprehensive analysis of interference in real MQ-SSDs, and find four major interference sources: (1) the intensity of requests sent by each application, (2) differences in request access patterns, (3) the ratio of reads to writes, and (4) garbage collection.

We perform a comprehensive analysis of interference in real MQ-SSDs, and find four major interference sources: (1) the intensity of requests sent by each application, (2) differences in request access patterns, (3) the ratio of reads to writes, and (4) garbage collection.
To alleviate unfairness in MQ-SSDs, we propose the Flash-Level INterference-aware scheduler (FLIN).
